questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE – STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

questions.text: Which of these is the most common type of hernia in females? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal

 

While it is commonly believed that femoral hernias are the most frequent type of hernia in females, this is not the case. The most common type of hernia in both males and females is the inguinal hernia, specifically the indirect inguinal hernia.

 

Inguinal hernias occur due to a weakness in the abdominal wall and the presence of a natural opening, the deep inguinal ring. Indirect inguinal hernias, which pass through this deep ring, are particularly common. Although femoral hernias are more commonly seen in women than in men, their overall incidence is much lower compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal: This type of hernia is less common than indirect inguinal hernias and occurs due to weakness in the floor of the inguinal canal. It is not the most common type in females.

 

Option C. Femoral: Although more common in women than in men, femoral hernias have a much lower overall incidence compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Obturator: This is a rare type of hernia and is not commonly seen in the general population, including females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of hernia in females, as in males, is the indirect inguinal hernia. Despite the misconception, femoral hernias, though more common in women than men, are less frequent overall.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: Breast cancer of size 6 x 8 cm with dimpling with invasion of Pectoralis Major and ipsilateral matted axillary nodes belongs to what TNM stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3N2M0

 

  • Tumor size > 5 cm = T3
  • Skin dimpling does not affect T stage (common misconception)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major does not affect T stage
  • Only skin ulceration, peau d'orange, or satellite nodules make it T4b
  • Ipsilateral matted axillary nodes = N2
  • No mention of distant metastasis = M0


Other Options: 

 

Option B. T4bN1M0:

 

  • Skin dimpling alone does not make it T4b
  • N1 represents mobile nodes, while the question mentions matted nodes (N2)
     

Option C. T4aN2M0:

 

  • T4a represents chest wall invasion (not including pectoralis major)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major alone does not make it T4a
     

Option D. T2N2M1:

 

  • T2 is for tumors 2-5 cm, this tumor is > 5 cm

  • No evidence of distant metastasis (M1)

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skin dimpling and pectoralis major invasion do not affect T stage in breast cancer TNM staging
  • T3 stage is for tumors > 5 cm
  • Matted axillary nodes represent N2 disease

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has recently undergone total thyroidectomy for a thyroid mass. The histopathological examination shows papillary thyroid cancer. What would be the further management of this patient?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radioiodine scan

 

After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, the usual next step is a Radioiodine scan to detect any remaining thyroid tissue and potential metastasis. Based on the findings, further therapeutic radioactive iodine might be administered. Regular follow-up, including blood tests and imaging studies, will be necessary to monitor for any recurrence or metastasis.

 

Radioiodine scan (also known as I-123 or RAI scan) is often used post-thyroidectomy to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease. This aids in planning for subsequent radioactive iodine therapy to ablate residual tissue or treat metastatic disease. The patient is usually given a dose of radioactive iodine, which is taken up by any remaining thyroid cells, and then imaging is done to determine the distribution of the radioactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiation: Incorrect in the majority of cases. External beam radiation therapy is not typically the first line of treatment for papillary thyroid cancer. It might be considered in rare situations, such as for certain anaplastic thyroid cancers or when the cancer is very aggressive, doesn't take up iodine, and other treatments haven't worked.

 

Option C. Conservative management: Incorrect. Simply monitoring without further treatment is not the standard of care for papillary thyroid cancer after surgery, especially when the cancer is of significant size, shows aggressive features, or has spread to lymph nodes or distant sites. Typically, the patient will undergo some form of adjuvant therapy or monitoring, often starting with a radioiodine scan.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy: Incorrect for early and most intermediate stages. Chemotherapy isn't a standard treatment for most thyroid cancers. However, it might be recommended for people who don't respond to standard treatments and for certain types of aggressive thyroid cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, a radioiodine scan is typically used to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease, guiding further therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: Based on the given X-ray image, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray shows free air under both domes of diaphragm, which is pathognomonic of hollow viscus perforation. This occurs when there is a breach in the wall of a hollow organ (like stomach or intestine) leading to escape of air into the peritoneal cavity. The free air rises and collects under the diaphragm, visible as a dark area on chest X-ray when the patient is erect X-ray.


The common causes include:

 

  • Peptic ulcer perforation (most common)
  • Traumatic bowel injury
  • Typhoid ileal perforation
  • Appendicular perforation

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sub-acute intestinal obstruction: Incorrect because X-ray would show dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels, not free air under the diaphragm

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Incorrect as X-ray would show dilated bowel loops with air throughout, no free air under diaphragm

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: Incorrect as X-ray would show homogeneous opacity in pleural space with obliteration of costophrenic angles, not free air under diaphragm

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hollow viscus perforation is diagnosed radiologically by the presence of free air under the diaphragm, typically seen in an erect chest X-ray or CT scan of the abdomen. It is a surgical emergency requiring immediate laparotomy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of prior neck radiation for lymphoma is diagnosed with 2 x 3 cm papillary thyroid cancer. No lymph node enlargement is present. What is the treatment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: 

 

Total thyroidectomy is now the preferred approach only for those differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) at higher risk for recurrence:

  • Tumor at least  4 cm 
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension 
  • Evidence of metastatic disease 
  • Radiation-induced DTC (mentioned in the history) 
  • Familial non-medullary thyroid cancer 
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemithyroidectomy:

 

  • History of radiation is a high-risk feature requiring total thyroidectomy
  • Hemithyroidectomy is reserved for low-risk, small unifocal tumors without risk factors

 

Option C. Hemithyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • MRND is not indicated without clinical lymphadenopathy
  • MRND is mainly done for medullary thyroid cancer
  • Hemithyroidectomy is inadequate given the radiation history

 

Option D. Total Thyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • No lymph node involvement noted
  • For papillary thyroid cancer without lymphadenopathy, central compartment (level VI) clearance may be done, but not MRND

 

Educational Objective: 

 

History of radiation exposure is an absolute indication for total thyroidectomy in differentiated thyroid cancer, regardless of tumor size.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.

 

Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:

  • Pioglitazone: A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • Aristolochic acid: Found in some herbal remedies.
  • Phenacetin: An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • Aminosalicylates: Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

questions.text: What treatment should be avoided for a male patient in his mid-40s who was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident, and presents with a heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and an X-ray image of his chest? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest tube insertion

 

Given Scenario with x ray shows left sided traumatic diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of stomach. Nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia can be done. However, intercostal drain should not be put as it would traumatic the herniated content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The provided image displays an elevated left hemidiaphragm with stomach herniated into thorax, likely due to a diaphragmatic hernia resulting from blunt trauma in a road traffic accident.

 

  • Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated
  • Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.
  • To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in the TNM stage T4b of breast cancer? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Skin erythema involving > 1/3rd surface

 

T4b stage of breast cancer involves skin invasion with specific manifestations. According to TNM staging, T4b includes direct skin invasion presenting as ulceration of the skin, satellite skin nodules, or peau d'orange (orange peel appearance due to lymphatic obstruction). These changes must involve less than one-third of the breast skin surface. When skin erythema involves more than one-third of the breast surface (>1/3rd surface), it is classified as T4d (inflammatory breast cancer), not T4b. Therefore, skin erythema involving more than one-third of the surface is not included in T4b staging but rather defines T4d disease. The distinction is important because inflammatory breast cancer (T4d) has a different prognosis and treatment approach compared to T4b disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulceration: This is incorrect as an answer because ulceration is indeed included in T4b staging. Skin ulceration represents direct tumor invasion through the dermis and epidermis, which is a defining feature of T4b breast cancer.

 

Option B. Satellite nodules: This is incorrect as an answer because satellite nodules are included in T4b staging. These are small tumor deposits in the skin separate from the main tumor mass, indicating advanced local disease with skin involvement.

 

Option D. Peau d'orange: This is incorrect as an answer because peau d'orange is a classic sign included in T4b staging. It results from dermal lymphatic invasion causing skin edema and dimpling that resembles orange peel, representing skin involvement without necessarily being inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T4b breast cancer includes skin ulceration, satellite nodules, and peau d'orange affecting less than one-third of breast skin surface, while skin erythema involving more than one-third of the surface is classified as T4d (inflammatory breast cancer).

 

TNM Staging for Breast Cancer:

 

T - Tumor Size (maximum)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Graves' disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. What medication can be administered in the preoperative period to minimize intraoperative bleeding in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium iodide

 

Potassium iodide, which can be given 10 days before the surgery to reduce intraoperative bleeding during total thyroidectomy. This is because iodide alone produces transient remission and may reduce vascularity, thereby marginally improving safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to prepare the patient for surgery by inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and causing beta-adrenergic blockade. However, it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding during thyroidectomy. It is beneficial in thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Propylthiouracil: Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. It is used to render the patient euthyroid before surgery, but it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Betamethasone: Betamethasone is a glucocorticoid that reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, it is not used preoperatively in thyroidectomy to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in an overactive thyroid gland, known as hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing it to produce more thyroid hormone than the body needs. As a result, the thyroid gland becomes hyperactive, leading to various symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. Graves' disease is the most prevalent cause of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of thromboangitis obliterans except:(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absence of popliteal pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Thromboangitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) classically presents with a triad of symptoms including intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. Buerger's disease typically affects small and medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery rather than the popliteal artery itself. The disease primarily affects young male smokers under 40 years of age. The popliteal pulse is usually preserved in Buerger's disease, as the pathology affects more distal vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raynaud's phenomenon - This is part of the classic triad of Buerger's disease, characterized by cyclical color changes in digits upon exposure to cold, stress, or vibratory tools due to vasospasm.

 

Option B. Claudication of extremities - Intermittent claudication is a core feature of Buerger's disease and part of the classic triad.

 

Option D. Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis - This is another component of the classic triad of Buerger's disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Buerger's disease (thromboangitis obliterans) typically affects small to medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery, presenting with the classic triad of intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon, while preserving more proximal pulses such as the popliteal pulse.

questions.text: A patient with loin pain underwent retrograde ureter pyelogram to determine the cause of the pain. What is the likely cause of the pain as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydronephrosis

 

The presence of dilated clubbed calyces and a stricture at the left ureteropelvic junction in the given image is indicative of hydronephrosis, which is caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow in the pelvicalyceal system. This condition can arise when there's an obstruction preventing urine from draining out of the kidney and down the ureter. Over time, this causes the kidney to swell and its internal structures, like the calyces, to dilate. Retrograde ureteropyelogram can reveal the classic signs of hydronephrosis such as dilated and clubbed calyces, and any blockage, for instance, at the ureteropelvic junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duplex kidney: A duplex kidney is a congenital anomaly where the kidney has two collecting systems. This means there are two ureters draining a single kidney, although sometimes the two ureters can fuse before entering the bladder. A retrograde ureteropyelogram can identify a duplex system by visualizing the two separate collecting systems and ureters. However, this option isn't the described condition causing the pain based on the information provided.

 

Option C. Renal carcinoma: Patients with renal carcinoma are likely to present with gross hematuria, while pain is late feature. While a retrograde ureteropyelogram can show filling defects, irregularities, or obstructions in the renal collecting system which could be caused by a tumor, it isn't the primary tool used for diagnosing renal carcinoma. Imaging methods like CT scans or MRIs are more commonly used for visualizing renal masses.

 

Option D. Renal stone: Kidney stones (renal calculi) present with flank pain and hematuria. On a retrograde ureteropyelogram, a kidney stone might show up as a filling defect or blockage. The location, size, and shape of the stone can often be identified. However, based on the information provided, the image indicates hydronephrosis and not a stone.

 

Educational Objective:


Hydronephrosis is characterized by the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to an obstruction in urine flow, leading to swelling of the kidney and pain, typically visualized via imaging like a retrograde ureteropyelogram.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein’s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a contraindication to BCT? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tumor limited to one quadrant

 

Breast Conservation Therapy (BCT) involves wide local excision of the tumor followed by radiation therapy. A tumor limited to one quadrant is actually suitable for BCT as it allows for adequate wide local excision with clear margins while preserving most of the breast tissue. BCT is feasible when the tumor is localized and can be completely excised with negative margins while maintaining acceptable cosmesis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior chest radiation: Incorrect. This is a contraindication to BCT because the breast tissue has already received radiation, and re-irradiation would exceed tissue tolerance, leading to severe complications including tissue necrosis and poor wound healing.

 

Option B. Involved margins after resection: Incorrect. This is a contraindication, especially if margins remain positive after two or more attempts at re-excision. Positive margins indicate incomplete tumor removal and high risk of local recurrence.

 

Option C. Scleroderma: Incorrect. This is a contraindication because scleroderma and other connective tissue disorders cause poor tolerance to radiation therapy, resulting in severe fibrosis, contractures, and poor cosmetic outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor limited to one quadrant is not a contraindication to BCT; rather, it is an ideal scenario for breast conservation therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form a boundary of the 'Triangle of Doom'? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Inguinal ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The "Triangle of Doom" is an important anatomical danger zone encountered during laparoscopic hernia repair. This triangle contains critical structures, including the external iliac vessels that must be avoided during mesh fixation and dissection. This triangle is bounded by the vas deferens medially, the gonadal vessels laterally, and the peritoneal reflection forming the base. The inguinal ligament is not a boundary of this triangle in the laparoscopic perspective.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Vas Deferens - This is an incorrect answer because the vas deferens forms the medial boundary of the Triangle of Doom in laparoscopic hernia repair, creating an essential landmark surgeons must identify to avoid vascular injury.
  • Option B. Gonadal vessels - This is an incorrect answer because the gonadal vessels (testicular or ovarian vessels) form the lateral boundary of the Triangle of Doom, serving as a crucial landmark during laparoscopic hernia procedures.
  • Option C. Peritoneal reflection - This is an incorrect answer because the peritoneal reflection forms the base of the Triangle of Doom in the laparoscopic view, completing the triangular area containing the dangerous external iliac vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the boundaries and contents of the Triangle of Doom is essential for safe laparoscopic hernia repair, as inadvertent dissection or tack placement in this area can result in catastrophic vascular injury.

choices.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

 

The different levels of triage in emergency care are immediate, delayed, and minimal triage.

 

Immediate triage (red tag) is the highest priority and is given to patients who have life-threatening injuries or illnesses that require prompt medical attention. Examples of immediate triage include patients with severe bleeding or difficulty breathing.

 

Delayed triage (yellow tag) is given to patients who have injuries or illnesses that are not immediately life-threatening but require medical attention. Examples of delayed triage include patients with open fractures or moderate burns.

 

Minimal triage (green tag) is given to patients who have minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention. Examples of minimal triage include patients with minor cuts or bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the upper GI endoscopy image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal varices

 

The image shows dilated column of veins in the veins suggestive of esophageal varices. They are seen in portal hypertension and present with hematemesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrett’s esophagus: Characterised by salmon coloured tongue like patches at GE junction

 

 

Option C. Gastric erosions: Lesions seen in stomach due to H. Pylori.

 

 

 

Option D. Esophageal candida: Appear as milky/curdy white patches.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated column of veins in esophagus represent varices.

questions.text:
Mrs. Smith has been referred to the plastic surgery department for the reconstruction of a large wound on her thigh. After a thorough examination, the surgeon decides to perform a skin graft. While discussing the procedure with Mrs. Smith, the surgeon explains the difference between split skin and full-thickness skin grafts. Identify the true statement regarding split thickness and full-thickness skin grafts:(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Primary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  2. Secondary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  3. Primary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
  4. Secondary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Split skin grafts are partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a part of the dermis, while full-thickness grafts consist of the epidermis along with the entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Primary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to passive recoil of the elastin fibers of the dermis in full thickness grafts. Since full-thickness grafts have more dermis (implying more elastin fibers), they undergo more primary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Secondary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to the pull of myofibroblasts, and it occurs over time, when the transplanted graft starts healing. Full-thickness grafts have more ability to resist the pull of myofibroblasts, hence they have less secondary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Primary contracture: FTSG

 

Secondary contracture: STSG

 

Thus, statements 2 and 3 are correct.

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: A 67 yrs. old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination, the patient has a history of alcohol abuse and poorly controlled diabetes, and laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated blood glucose levels. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

  • The image and clinical scenario suggest Fournier's gangrene, which is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and a surgical emergency.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by mixed bacterial flora, often associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation, or trauma.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene include erythema, swelling, pain, and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions.
  • Correct. Fournier's gangrene involves a mixed infection with both aerobic (oxygen-using) and anaerobic (not oxygen-using) bacteria. The presence of multiple bacterial types contributes to the rapid progression and severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy: Incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is typically used for the treatment of gas gangrene caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. While C. perfringens can sometimes be a part of the mixed bacterial flora in Fournier's gangrene, the condition itself is not specifically gas gangrene, and thus anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed: Incorrect. A bilateral orchidectomy, or the removal of both testes, is not a standard treatment for Fournier's gangrene. Testes are typically spared in Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Option D. Compulsory urinary diversion is performed: Incorrect. While urinary diversion might be considered in some cases where the urethra is compromised or if there's significant involvement of the urogenital structures, it's not a compulsory or routine part of the management of Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a surgical emergency characterized by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacterial infection of the genital and perianal regions, often associated with underlying conditions like diabetes and malnutrition.
  • It requires prompt surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about triage? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow: urgent care needed

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: ambulatory - This is incorrect because red is used for conditions requiring immediate attention, not for ambulatory patients.

 

Option C. Black: minor injuries - This is incorrect because black is used for patients who are moribund or dead, not for minor injuries.

 

Option D. Green: immediate life threatening - This is incorrect because green is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries, not for life-threatening conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yellow in triage signifies that urgent care is needed, such as for open fractures or degloving injuries.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

The given scenario and image is most likely to be of Fournier gangrene which is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

 

FOURNIER’S GANGRENE

 

  • Synergistic gangrene of scrotum and perineum
  • Limited to skin and fascial planes - type of necrotising fasciitis
  • Never breaches the tunica, testis always spared
  • Risk factors - Low immunity, uncontrolled diabetes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases: Anti-gas gangrene serum is obsolete now.

 

Option B. Urinary diversion is the next step: Urinary diversion is not the next best step.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done: Testes are preserved during debridement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

choices.text: Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

questions.text: A patent underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The histopathology specimen reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

 

  • In the scenario of a patient with a gallbladder carcinoma discovered incidentally following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, where the carcinoma has invaded the muscularis propria, the next step in management should focus on ensuring complete removal of any residual malignant tissue and preventing local recurrence.
  • Radical or wide excision of the gallbladder fossa is the recommended course of action. This involves excising the gallbladder bed to the level of the liver parenchyma and possibly lymph node dissection to ensure any potential spread or residual disease is addressed. This approach is supported by the need to achieve negative margins, as gallbladder cancer can be aggressive and has a tendency to infiltrate the liver and surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy and B. Chemotherapy might be considered as adjunct therapies depending on the stage of the cancer, pathological findings from the re-excision, and the patient's overall health status. However, they are not the primary step immediately following the discovery of invasive gallbladder cancer in a post-cholecystectomy specimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical/wide excision of the GB fossa is indeed the appropriate next step to prevent local recurrence and potentially improve survival outcomes. This decision is based on the depth of tumor invasion and the general aggressiveness of gallbladder cancers.

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reef knot

 

The image shows a reef knot, also called as square knot:

  • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot
  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

 

Other Surgical knots

 

Granny Knot

  • Two Throws in the Same Direction
  • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

 

 

Option C: Surgeon’s Knot

  • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
  • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
  • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

Option A: Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch)

  • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
  • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
  • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Other Options :

 

 

 

Educational Objective: The reef knot has

 

  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

choices.text: 2-3 hours after a hyperosmolar meal

questions.text: All of the following are true about Delayed or Late Dumping Syndrome, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Late dumping syndrome is a consequence of peptic ulcer surgery characterized by reactive hypoglycemia occurring typically 1-3 hours after meals. It develops when carbohydrate-rich food causes a rapid rise in blood glucose, triggering an excessive insulin response that leads to subsequent hypoglycemia. Diarrhea is typical of early dumping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2-3 hours after hyperosmolar meal - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping occurs in the second hour after meals, typically 1-3 hours post-meal. The timing is correct.

 

Option B. Reactive hypoglycemia - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping is defined as reactive hypoglycemia caused by the carbohydrate load in the small bowel, leading to a rise in plasma glucose, which triggers insulin release and subsequent hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Neuroglucopenic symptoms are prominent - TRUE for late dumping. The symptoms of late dumping include tremor, faintness, prostration, dizziness, and palpitations, which are manifestations of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Late dumping syndrome presents 1-3 hours after meals with hypoglycemic symptoms (tremors, faintness, dizziness) due to reactive hypoglycemia, while diarrhea is characteristic of early dumping syndrome which occurs immediately after meals.

 

 

Features of Early and Late Dumping

questions.text: An inguinal hernia with acute appendicitis occurring in the sac is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Amyand’s Hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically defined as an inguinal hernia where the content is the appendix. When the appendix becomes inflamed within the hernia sac, it represents a case of acute appendicitis occurring within an Amyand's hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Richter's Hernia: This occurs when only part of the bowel wall circumference is the content of the hernia. It typically doesn't present with intestinal obstruction but can directly progress to strangulation.
  • Option B. Littre's Hernia: This is defined as a hernia where the content is Meckel's diverticulum, not the appendix.
  • Option D. Maydl's Hernia: This refers to a double loop of intestine within the hernia sac.

 

Named Hernias at a glance:

  1. Omentocele - Content is omentum
  2. Enterocele - Content is intestine
  3. Richter's - Part of bowel wall circumference is in the sac
  4. Littre's - Content is Meckel's diverticulum
  5. Maydl's - Double loop of intestine
  6. Amyand's - Content is appendix
  7. Sliding hernia - Organs like cecum (right) or sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and form a part of the wall of the sac

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically an inguinal hernia containing the appendix, regardless of whether the appendix is inflamed or normal.

questions.text: What would be the next suitable examination for a chronic smoker, aged 40, who is experiencing blue discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duplex scan

 

The duplex scan is a type of ultrasound that combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound. It can visualize the structure of blood vessels and the flow of blood within them. It is non-invasive, doesn't require the use of contrast media, and can provide immediate results. Given the patient's symptoms of blue discoloration of the toe (suggesting compromised blood flow) and intermittent claudication (pain in the legs while walking, indicating peripheral artery disease), a duplex scan is an excellent first choice to evaluate the patency of the arteries and the location and severity of any blockages. For a chronic smoker with these symptoms, a duplex scan is a commonly used initial diagnostic tool to evaluate peripheral arterial disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Angiography: Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is a diagnostic tool that combines X-ray technology with computer imaging to visualize blood flow in the arteries. While it can provide detailed images of blood vessels and can identify blockages or other vascular problems, it requires the injection of a contrast medium, exposes the patient to radiation, and might not be the first-line diagnostic tool in this scenario.

 

Option B. MR Angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that looks specifically at blood vessels. It provides detailed images of arteries and can be useful in detecting vascular problems. However, it might not be the first choice for initial evaluation, especially when quicker, less expensive, and equally informative tests are available, like the duplex scan.

 

Option C. Digital subtraction angiography: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive procedure that involves injecting a contrast medium into the blood vessels and taking X-ray images. It provides detailed visualization of the inner structures of blood vessels and is particularly useful for planning interventions. However, due to its invasive nature, it is typically done if planning a vascular intervention like balloon dilation or stenting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Chronic smoking can cause peripheral arterial disease, which can present with bluish discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication.
  • Duplex Scanning is a non-invasive technique that uses ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel and can be used to investigate this condition.
  • Duplex Scanning allows for detailed visualization of blood flow within the vessel, with different colors indicating changes in direction and velocity of flow.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgical resection for a pathology in the left lung. Pre-operatively the left lung collapsed. After the surgery the lung has expanded. What can be the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left pneumothorax

 

The given radiograph shows a distinct left pleural line with absent bronchovascular markings, indicative of a collapsed lung on the left side. These features are characteristic of a pneumothorax. A pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse. The surgical intervention likely addressed the underlying cause of the pneumothorax, leading to the re-expansion of the lung post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right pneumothorax: A right pneumothorax involves air accumulating in the pleural space of the right lung, causing it to collapse. In this case, the pathology and the collapse were observed in the left lung, making a right pneumothorax an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade is a condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial space, compressing the heart and impairing its function. While it can affect lung function due to decreased cardiac output, it does not directly cause a lung to collapse. Thus, it is not a likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pneumonia: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in the lungs, which can fill with fluid or pus. Although pneumonia can lead to respiratory symptoms and affect lung expansion, it does not directly cause a lung to collapse like a pneumothorax. Pneumonia typically presents with signs such as consolidations or ground-glass opacities on a radiograph.

 

Educational Objective:


A pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of a distinct pleural line and absence of bronchovascular markings, indicating a collapsed lung.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child was brought to the emergency with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. He was dehydrated. What should be corrected before performing surgical treatment in this baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

The child presents with recurrent non-bilious vomiting, which is a classic sign of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). IHPS is a condition in infants causing severe vomiting due to the thickening of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction.

 

Patients with IHPS often develop a specific electrolyte imbalance characterized by hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. The vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid), resulting in low chloride levels and secondary metabolic alkalosis. This condition also results in potassium loss, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Before performing surgical treatment (such as a pyloromyotomy, often referenced in this context as the Ramstedt procedure), it is crucial to correct the electrolyte imbalance to stabilize the patient. The primary focus is on correcting hypokalemia because potassium is essential for normal cellular function and cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: This condition involves high potassium levels, which is not typically seen in patients with IHPS. Instead, these patients usually have low potassium levels due to vomiting.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: While hyponatremia (low sodium levels) can occur, it is generally not as significant or immediately life-threatening as hypokalemia in the context of IHPS.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels are not characteristic of IHPS. The vomiting associated with IHPS more commonly leads to losses of electrolytes like potassium and chloride, not an increase in sodium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is often associated with hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Correction of hypokalemia is essential before surgical intervention.

choices.text: It is caused by staphylococcus only
It is a case of testicular torsion

questions.text: A 40-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the correct statement about this condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The testis remains unaffected

 

The patient's presentation, along with the examination findings, suggest Fournier's gangrene. This is a life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal and genital regions requiring prompt medical and surgical intervention.

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is characterized by rapid progression and extensive tissue necrosis. It is a polymicrobial infection often involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria from gastrointestinal or genitourinary sources. Immediate treatment includes surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

 

The infection in Fournier's gangrene usually affects superficial tissues and skin but spares the testes due to their separate blood supply from the testicular artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused by staphylococcus only: Incorrect. While Staphylococcus species can be involved, Fournier's gangrene is typically polymicrobial, involving multiple bacteria such as E. coli, Klebsiella, and anaerobes, along with staphylococci.

 

Option C. It is a self-resolving condition: Incorrect. Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressing and severe condition that requires urgent surgical and medical treatment. Without intervention, it can lead to sepsis and be fatal.

 

Option D. It is a case of testicular torsion: Incorrect. Testicular torsion involves twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to acute severe scrotal pain and ischemia of the testis. This condition is different from Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier's gangrene is a severe necrotizing infection of the perineal and genital regions, often sparing deeper structures like the testes. Immediate surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics are critical for management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: All of the following contribute to the circle of death, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Femoral artery

 

Explanation:

 

The "circle of death" refers to the vascular anastomotic ring formed around the femoral ring, which is critical during femoral hernia and laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery. This dangerous vascular circle is formed by the obturator artery, aberrant obturator artery (when present), and inferior epigastric artery. The femoral artery does not contribute to this vascular circle - it runs lateral to the femoral vein and outside the femoral ring.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Obturator artery: This vessel normally originates from the internal iliac artery and contributes to the vascular anastomosis around the femoral ring.
  • Option B. Aberrant Obturator artery: When present, this anomalous vessel arises from the inferior epigastric artery (instead of from the internal iliac) and courses around the femoral ring to reach the obturator foramen, creating a significant surgical risk.
  • Option C. Inferior Epigastric artery: This vessel runs along the medial border of the deep inguinal ring and can anastomose with the obturator artery, forming part of the "circle of death."

 

Femoral region anatomy relevant to hernias: The femoral ring has rigid boundaries including the inguinal ligament superiorly, femoral vein laterally, pubic arc (pecten pubis) inferiorly, and lacunar ligament medially. The contents of the femoral canal include fat and the lymph node of Cloquet.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During femoral hernia repair, particularly when making an incision in the lacunar ligament to relieve strangulation, surgeons must be extremely cautious of the "circle of death" formed by the obturator and inferior epigastric vessels - not the femoral artery.

questions.text: Which of these is an indication for giving adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after resection and MRND? (An image of the flap reconstruction was shown).  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extranodal extension

 

Extranodal extension (ENE) refers to the spread of cancer beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding tissues. This feature has recently been added as a significant factor in the staging and management of head and neck cancers, including oral malignancies. ENE is associated with a poorer prognosis due to its aggressive nature and higher likelihood of recurrence. Therefore, it is a major criterion for adjuvant radiotherapy following surgery and MRND (modified radical neck dissection), as radiotherapy can help reduce the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple LN metastases: While having multiple involved lymph nodes is a sign of advanced disease, it alone does not necessarily mandate adjuvant radiotherapy unless combined with other factors, such as large nodal size (>3 cm) or other minor criteria.

Option C. T3 tumor: T3 tumors are generally considered advanced due to their size and extent. However, adjuvant radiotherapy is more strongly indicated when other adverse pathological features, such as ENE or involved surgical margins, are present.

 

Option D. Close margin (1.5-2 mm): Close surgical margins indicate that the tumor was resected near the boundary of normal tissue, increasing the risk of residual disease. However, a close margin alone is not as critical as an involved margin (<1 mm) and typically requires radiotherapy only if combined with other adverse features.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Extranodal extension is a key indication for adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after surgical resection and MRND due to its significant impact on prognosis and risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia 

 

  • The clinical picture of a cyanotic newborn with respiratory distress and auscultation revealing bowel sounds in the left hemithorax, combined with chest X-ray showing multiple air-fluid levels, is suggestive of a congenital anomaly that allows abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. 
  • CDH is a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development and causing respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth. The presence of bowel sounds in the thorax and air-fluid levels on X-ray are indicative of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a congenital heart defect that includes four abnormalities: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It leads to cyanotic congenital heart disease but does not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option C. Transposition of the great vessels: This is another congenital heart defect where the major vessels (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) are switched. It results in cyanosis but would not cause bowel sounds in the chest or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal fistula: This condition involves an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, which can lead to respiratory distress due to aspiration, but it would not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or the radiographic appearance of air-fluid levels as seen with CDH.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is most likely responsible for the clinical findings of cyanosis, respiratory distress, and bowel sounds in the chest of a newborn, along with air-fluid levels on chest X-ray.

choices.text: Cyst is opened and drainage done

questions.text: Incorrect statement about choledocal cyst is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyst is opened and drainage done 

 

The preferred treatment for choledochal cysts is not merely opening and draining them, but rather complete surgical removal of the cyst (cyst excision) and reconstruction of the biliary drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma: The risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts can be significantly higher than in the general population. Regular monitoring and prophylactic surgical intervention are often recommended to manage this risk.

 

Option C. Todani classification used for grading: The Todani classification is indeed used to categorize choledochal cysts based on their anatomical location and type. This classification helps guide the treatment approach and prognostic assessment, making it fundamental in the management of choledochal cysts.

 

Option D. Associated with abnormal biliopancreatic junction: Choledochal cysts are often associated with an abnormal junction of the pancreatic and biliary ducts. This anomaly can lead to pancreatic juices refluxing into the bile duct, increasing the risk of inflammation and subsequent complications like cyst formation and malignancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the management of choledochal cysts involves a comprehensive approach considering the risk of malignancy, the appropriate surgical intervention usually entails the complete removal of the cyst and careful reconstruction of the biliary system, not just simple drainage.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text: Before conducting an A-V fistula procedure, which of the following tests is typically conducted? The image of the test is given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allen's test

 

The given image represents Allen’s test, which indicates the patency of the radial and ulna artery in supplying the hand. Both arteries are compressed alternatively, to check if limb will survive in absence of radial artery (which will be now used in creation of AV fistula).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adson's test: Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles. Patient is asked to turn his head to affected side and take a deep breath. Ipsilateral radial pulse will become weak in thoracic outlet syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Elevated arm stress test: Elevated arm stress test is a diagnostic tool used in the identification of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. The patient is asked to abduct his shoulder and flex his forearm and open and close his fists. In presence of thoracic outlet syndrome, the affected limb will get cramps (ischemic) or paresthesia (neurogenic).

 

 

Option D. Nicoladoni's test: Nicoladoni's test is to be elicited in cases of AV fistula. There is slowing of heart rate in response to manual compression of fistula.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

questions.text: A young patient suffered from Blunt trauma to the abdomen and was brought to the Emergency room. He is unstable with a blood pressure of 90/60 mm of Hg. You are the doctor, basic resuscitation is done with Intravenous fluids, FAST is positive. He is not improving despite Intravenous fluids. The next step is? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exploratory Laparotomy

 

Given the described scenario with an unstable patient and a positive FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma), the most immediate and effective step to address potential life-threatening injuries would be an exploratory laparotomy. In cases of trauma where the patient is hemodynamically unstable and there is evidence of intra-abdominal bleeding, exploratory laparotomy allows for direct visualization and control of bleeding sources, as well as repair of any injuries. This procedure is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NCCT (Non-Contrast Computed Tomography): While NCCT can provide valuable diagnostic information regarding many conditions, it is not suitable for an unstable patient with potential intra-abdominal bleeding. This imaging modality takes time and the patient might not be stable enough to undergo it safely.

Option C. Laparoscopy: Laparoscopy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to examine the organs inside the abdomen. However, it is more commonly used in elective surgical procedures rather than in emergencies, especially when the patient is unstable. It may not provide the access or control needed to address significant injuries quickly in a trauma setting.

  •  

Option D. PET (Positron Emission Tomography): PET is a functional imaging technique that is used to observe metabolic processes in the body. It is not typically used in the acute trauma setting and would not be appropriate for a patient who is hemodynamically unstable with a suspicion of internal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a trauma patient with hemodynamic instability and a positive FAST, exploratory laparotomy is the definitive diagnostic and therapeutic intervention to control bleeding and repair injuries.

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

To summarize, each of the mentioned criteria - size, symptomatic presentation, and rapid growth - are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms. Thus, the answer is: D. All of the above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Size more than 5.5 cm in males:  An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that is greater than 5.5 cm in diameter has an increased risk of rupture. The risk of rupture and complications rises significantly as the size of the aneurysm increases. For this reason, surgical intervention is typically recommended when an AAA reaches this size in males.

 

Option B. Patient is experiencing abdominal pain: Abdominal pain can be a sign that the aneurysm is expanding or is about to rupture. If a patient presents with abdominal pain and an AAA, it's often treated as a surgical emergency. The pain might be caused by the aneurysm pressing on surrounding structures or due to impending rupture.

 

Option C. Expansion of >0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA is another indicator of increased rupture risk. An expansion of more than 0.5 cm in 6 months indicates that the aneurysm is growing quickly. Rapid growth can be a sign of structural changes in the aneurysm wall that increase the risk of rupture. Therefore, even if the AAA is smaller than the usual 5.5 cm threshold, if it's growing quickly, surgical intervention is typically considered.

 

Educational Objective:


Abdominal aortic aneurysms require surgical intervention if the size exceeds 5.5 cm in males, the patient presents with abdominal pain, or if there is an expansion of more than 0.5 cm within 6 months.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in intercostal space

questions.text: What should be the treatment in a patient who presented in the emergency with respiratory distress, dilated neck veins and an Xray chest showing large amount of air on the left side along with mediastinal shift as shown? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wide bore needle insertion in intercostal space

 

The chest X-ray findings in this patient indicate a tension pneumothorax. The hallmarks on the X-ray include a large amount of air on the left side, a depressed diaphragm, an ipsilateral collapsed lung, a shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side, and the absence of bronchovascular markings on the affected side. These signs, combined with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory distress and dilated neck veins, confirm the diagnosis.

 

Management of tension pneumothorax involves immediate decompression to relieve the pressure. This is achieved by inserting a wide bore needle into the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line in children, or in the 5th intercostal space at the anterior axillary line in adults. This procedure allows the trapped air to escape, relieving the pressure on the lung and the mediastinum, thereby stabilizing the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endotracheal intubation: While endotracheal intubation is utilized in severe respiratory distress cases, it does not address the underlying cause of tension pneumothorax. The primary intervention required is immediate decompression.

 

Option C. Open thoracotomy: Open thoracotomy is a surgical procedure used for various thoracic conditions, including cardiac tamponade, but it is not the first-line treatment for tension pneumothorax. Immediate needle decompression is necessary for tension pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Pericardiocentesis: Pericardiocentesis involves the removal of fluid from the pericardial sac and is indicated for cardiac tamponade. It is not an appropriate treatment for tension pneumothorax, which requires decompression of the pleural space.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In the case of a tension pneumothorax, immediate decompression with a wide bore needle in the appropriate intercostal space is essential to relieve pressure and stabilize the patient.

choices.text: Watchful waiting and follow-up if symptomatic
Surgical repair on the next elective list
Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel
